Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies geometric figures that are given by equations, much like curves in the plane or surfaces in our three dimensional space. However, the figures studied here are higher, sometimes infinite dimensional, and they are given in terms of equations that involve complex numbers, rather than the real numbers that would occur with curves and surfaces. Even if these high dimensional and complex geometric figures are hard to visualize, as they do not fit in the space we are familiar with, they have proved to be most relevant to the description of our physical world, both on the atomic and subatomic levels (quantum theory), and on the astronomical scale (relativity). A central notion in geometry and its applications is that of curvature. A straight line has zero curvature: in general, curvature measures deviation of figures from straight. The project will explore curvature properties of figures that arise in various contexts, and implications that can be drawn if the curvature is known to be positive or negative.

The project has three parts. The first concerns the space of Kahler metrics on a compact complex manifold, an infinite dimensional space that is known to have non-positive curvature. The goal is to find shortest curves connecting points in this space, symmetries of the space, and investigate how symmetries interact with certain much studied functionals, such as Mabuchi's energy. The second and third parts concern general holomorphic Hilbert or Banach bundles, endowed with metrics. One problem is how curvature properties of the metrics change if the bundle and its metric are subjected to certain transformations. Another is to exploit curvature properties to estimate operators that arise in harmonic and complex analysis, by the technique of extrapolation. The methods will come from complex analysis and geometry, operator theory, and partial differential equations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The subject of this project was Complex Geometry, a discipline that studies complex manifolds and various structures on them.

 

Manifolds are generalizations of curves and surfaces in our 3--dimensional space, and like curves and surfaces one encounters in calculus, can be studied analytically by functions and equations. Three important features of the manifolds I work with are that they can be higher dimensional than curves and surfaces, in fact, sometimes they are infinite dimensional; they arise independently of an ambient space --- unlike the curves in calculus, that sit in our 3--space ---; and the functions that define them have complex, rather than real, variables.

 

Manifolds are similar to the plane, or in general, Euclidean spaces in that one can consider functions defined on them, and one can determine if a given function is continuous or differentiable. They are, however, different in some other ways: for example, one cannot measure the distance of two points on a manifold. Similarly, it makes sense to talk about curves in manifolds, but there is no way to measure their lengths. One can enrich the structure of a manifold, though, by endowing it with a so--called Riemannian metric, and in the case of a complex manifold, with a Kahler metric; the choice of such a metric allows one to measure distance on manifolds and to measure length of curves. As a side remark, Einstein's explanation of gravity is precisely in terms of metrics on a manifold, the space--time manifold.

 

Given a fixed manifold, there are infinitely many ways to endow it with a metric, and metrics with certain special properties (simple curvature) can facilitate the analysis of the manifold itself. The construction of such metrics is never easy though, and one typically has to work with the collection of all those metrics. In the context of complex manifolds, remarkably, all Kahler metrics on your complex manifold themselves form a manifold, albeit infinite dimensional! It is called the space of Kahler metrics. Since the 1980s various metrics on this space have been introduced, and shortest curves, `geodesics', between pairs of its points have been studied. By now it is well understood that these geodesics are of great importance to the analysis of the underlying finite dimensional complex manifold.

 

In my work I delineated a natural class of metrics on the space of Kahler metrics, that includes all those previously considered. While these metrics can wildly differ, I found that they have the same geodesics. For this result the concrete form of the metrics is irrelevant: what matters is an invariance property they have. I also found that geodesics in the space of Kahler metrics repel each other. Technically, if two points travel along two geodesics, their distance, measured in any of the invariant metrics, is a convex function of time.

 

To obtain these results, among other things I had to revisit work done in the first two decades of this century in a different branch of geometry, Symplectic Geometry. I simplified, generalized, and refined that work, concerning invariant metrics on a different infinite dimensional manifold, the group of symplectic transformations of a symplectic manifold. A transparent description of such metrics and of their finer properties allowed me to obtain the results on the space of Kahler metrics discussed above.
